awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: An archaeological examination of the cultural and ecological consequences of colonialism
awd_abstract_narration:
An enduring question for archaeologists is the nature of colonial encounters, specifically the small-scale dynamics between Indigenous groups and European settlers in the Americas. These questions are of particular salience where the overarching historical narrative portrays the interactions as controlled and dominated by Europeans, and emphasizes stereotyped depictions of the Indigenous groups living on the islands at contact. Scientists will conduct research to examine early colonial European-Indigenous interactions. A site, exposed by storm surge from Hurricane Maria in 2017, was an informal European trading complex established by colonial European settlers. It is situated along a protected bay on the Atlantic coastline and was one of the first sheltered anchorages for vessels voyaging from Africa and Europe. It was was one of few territories which continued for a significant time after contact to be controlled by Indigenous inhabitants. To ensure this work has broader impact beyond academia, the team will work collaboratively with the contemporary local community. Community members and residents will participate in excavations, and engage in frequent meetings on the interpretation of findings. To build local capacity for heritage protection, the team will hold a one-week archaeology “camp" and hire local research assistants to learn archaeological methods. In addition, with the support of local collaborator the project will contribute to the development of a museum and exhibits on the local colonial history.

The goal of the project is to characterize the nature of the relationship between the indigenous inhabitants and European settlers, and examine the political, economic, and socioecological realities of an informal trading encampment at a colonial frontier. The project team will conduct remote sensing, geophysical and sub-surface survey coring for environmental and geomorphological data, and excavation of archaeological and geological features. Through the application of these methods, this project investigates the development of the trading complex and surrounding enclave. This research connects with questions of how European settlers and Indigenous groups were entangled within the broader processes of colonialism and ecological transformations, exploring themes of Indigenous resilience and agency in the face of conquest.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
LaSoye was a 16th-18th century trading settlement on the northeast coast of the Caribbean Island of Dominica, and represents an important site of interaction between the Indigenous Kalinago who retained control of the island, and European settlers. Through archaeological survey and testing, we have developed a chronology for LaSoye that extends to nearly 2000 years ago, and established that what we initially thought was a European trading settlement was in fact occupied and controlled by the ancestral Kalinago into the early 18th century. Findings suggest that trading alliances with Europeans allowed for economic autonomy among Kalinago groups, showing their resilience and adaptiveness of communities amid precarity while Europeans aggressively vied for control and access to resources and territories.

 

Based on previous research and our own preliminary testing, we identified four areas (loci) at the site. LaSoye 2 (LS2) was identified through a mix of colonial period European artifacts mixed with Indigenous material culture, and located within 200 meters of La Soye 1 (LS1), a previously reported pre-Columbian occupation. This project also expanded prospection and archaeological testing into a third locus (LS3), which sits atop the ridge and headland that borders the southern edge of the bay, and LS4 (a probable indigenous petroglyph).

 

Our efforts in the first year began with several methods of survey, including geophysical (ground penetrating radar and magnetometry), remote sensing (LiDAR), and shovel testing. Additionally, we cored marine and coastal sediments to help understand the geological history of the bay. These methods allowed us target particular features and areas of high artifact density when we returned in 2023 and 2024 with the goal of exposing cultural deposits and delineating the extent of the site. Excavations identified evidence of five consecutive periods of occupation, which offer an opportunity to assess the material signatures of mixed Indigenous-European colonial settlements in the Eastern Caribbean. Using radiometric dating in combination with stratigraphic and material culture analysis we were able to establish a reliable chronology.

Phase 1 includes two cultural periods of Indigenous occupation. The oldest deposits were found on the hilltop (LS3). Shovel testing and expanded test units exposed a midden found at the top of the hill in an organic matrix, dating firmly to the Saladoid cultural period (ca. 400 BC to AD 600). Excavations also recovered material culture and architectural features from just before European contact, situated in the Suzan-Troumassoid cultural period (AD 1150/1200 to contact). We also recovered material remains from the period directly after initial European incursion into the Caribbean, when Dominica was a common stopover for ships after their Atlantic crossing to obtain food, water, and wood through exchange with Indigenous groups (Phase 2).

 

The third phase of occupation (roughly 1650-1730) represents the more established “trading settlement” period. This period is represented by an increase in European and Indigenous material culture, with a corresponding spike in radiocarbon dates. Materials and features from this phase suggest a re-intensification of Kalinago use of the site, and the more consistent presence of European residents. This pattern corresponds with a historically noted shift in settlement to the northeastern windward coast when Kalinago numbers on the island became low in the mid-late 17th century. This was also when the French and English were competing for trade alliances with Kalinago groups.

 

The data suggest that after a relatively long period of occupation the site was quickly, and perhaps traumatically, abandoned in the mid-1720s. An abundance of artifacts, scattered across a living surface and surrounding yard suggest a disruptive event. The actual event is unknown (earthquake, storm, or raid), but this timeline is consistent with the establishment of an imperial French presence on the island beginning in 1727 when the remaining Kalinago along the northwest coast moved just to the south, where the territory is situated today. The final phase represents British occupation and includes a late 18th to early 19th century military barrack and/or “watch” site at LS3 and several features and material culture deposits at LS2.

 

The archaeological data recovered reveals the nature of early colonial interactions on the Caribbean frontier, the significance of trade and exchange in colonial relationships, the resilience of Indigenous communities in Dominica, and the development of European privateering endeavors in the West Indies. This research is also of great significance for public history and heritage, as it examines one of the most significant and transitional moments of human history, the consequences of which resulted in the development of the modern world. The project included teams of researchers from our respective universities, the Kalinago Nation of Dominica, along with Dominican research assistants and partners. We focused on training and local capacity building throughout the duration of our research. This engagement and sharing of knowledge enhanced project outcomes by providing information significant cultural resources and enabling them to make informed decisions regarding protection and use of the area.
